questions.question_text:
A technician is cleaning up a warehouse and has several old CRT monitors and UPS units. The technician removes the batteries from the UPSs and wants to comply with proper disposal techniques.
Which of the following should the technician do NEXT to proceed with disposal of the batteries?

discussion.content: Should be C. The materials safety data sheet will detail chemical composition which will determine storage/disposal methods.
I agree answer should be C. Mike Myers has a practice question similar to this on his udemy course and has the answer as C.

Selected Answer: C
MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheet) - Standardized form that provides detailed information about potential environmental hazards and proper disposal methods associated with various computing components.
- Mike Meyers e-book

I understand where they got their answer, because you're cleaning out an old warehouse which might not have the safety data sheet readily available so you'll have to refer to the manufacturer's website or contact information, to get the information. I still think the answer should be C though because that will be where the information is obtained.
the same question is duplicated somewhere else in this website and states the answer should be C...
I as well feel C is the correct answer.

comments.content:
The Hazard Communication Standard (HCS) (29 CFR 1910.1200(g)), revised in 2012, requires that the chemical manufacturer, distributor, or importer provide Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) (formerly MSDSs or Material Safety Data Sheets) for each hazardous chemical to downstream users to communicate information on these hazards. The information contained in the SDS is largely the same as the MSDS, except now the SDSs are required to be presented in a consistent user-friendly, 16-section format. This brief provides guidance to help workers who handle hazardous chemicals to become familiar with the format and understand the contents of the SDSs.
*Section 13: Disposal Considerations (non-mandatory)*
from https://www.osha.gov/Publications/OSHA3514.html

discussion.content: I think answer B is correct, usually, MSDS provides more detailed instruction of the HAZMAT.

comments.content: sorry for the mistype, answer C should be correct.

choices.C: Review the material safety data sheet.
choices.B: Refer to the manufacturer's specific usage.
choices.D: Conduct an Internet search of disposal techniques.

questions.question_text:
Joe, an employee, took a company-issued Windows laptop home, but is having trouble connecting to any of the shares hosted on his home media server. Joe has verified he is connected to the Internet.
Which of the following would explain why Joe cannot access his personal shares?

discussion.content:
The correct answer is D: The laptop must join the HomeGroup.

Explanation
OBJ-1.6: The HomeGroup for the home network must be joined in order for the laptop to access the local network's shared files from the network's media server. The rest of the options can be dismissed since the laptop is able to access the internet successfully and browse the web.

comments.content: The question was missing what version of Windows since W10 does not support home group. Dion's question specifically states W8 to ensure you are aware that home group can be added. Answer is D per Betty.
Which word have mentioned the laptop is using W8?

discussion.content:
Joe has access to internet. Joe is trying to connect to his share media server at HOME using a business "issues" laptop. 
A: Ip addr has nothing to do here
B: VPN has nothing to do here since he's no trying to access resources of the business.
C: the internal windows defender firewall of the laptop might be set to allow only specific traffic based on the business policy. 
D. Homegroup is used on small office (20 pc's) and home. A business will have way more clients and will be using a domain instead.

The answer is C!

comments.content: The Company may have a domaine, but the user has the Problem at Home in his SOHO
This was my thoughts as well. Since its a enterprise issued laptop its connected to a domain and Joe has to abide by their polices.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The most likely explanation for why Joe cannot access his personal shares from a company-issued Windows laptop is that a corporate VPN is enabled. When connected to a VPN, the laptop will typically route all traffic through the corporate network, effectively blocking any access to local network resources. To access local resources while connected to a VPN, the VPN must be configured to allow split tunneling or Joe may need to disconnect from the VPN before attempting to access his home media server.

EXAM TIP HomeGroup works in Windows 7/8/8.1 and in early versions of Windows 10. Microsoft dropped support for HomeGroup in Windows 10 in 2018. You will see HomeGroup as an active feature of Windows on the CompTIA 1002 exam.
HomeGroup uses the idea that people want to share data, not folders. Most people just want to share their music, not their My Music or Music folder. So homegroups skip folders completely and share your Windows libraries. A homegroup connects a group of computers using a common password—no special user names required. Each computer can be a member of only one homegroup at a time. Let’s make a homegroup and see how this works.
KeyWord here is "Home media server". it is always confusing until you read the question over. take your time ladies and gents.
So, was Joe able to access his personal shares or not?
The correct answer is D

Selected Answer: C
Per https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/homegroup-from-start-to-finish-9f802c8c-900f-60fb-826f-6fe06add8fe9#ID0EBBD=Windows_10, HomeGroup has been removed from Windows 10.
Furthermore, if you work at enterprise company, they most likely block many functions on Windows OS and macOS such as share a folder within personal computer at home or airplay or even web browser setting for security purpose. It does with firewall rule or by OS. Some of setting you're not even able to change.

Selected Answer: D
HomeGroup is the correct answer.

comments.content: you should explain you're reasoning why

I was wrong, D is correct. Here is a similar question from Dions CompTIA A+ (220-1002) Test Prep, Exams and Simulations on Udemy.

Jason took home a company-issued Windows 8.1 laptop home to do some work. He successfully connected it to his home's wireless network and verified he could access the internet and browse his favorite websites. Unfortunately, Jason cannot access any of the network's shared files from his home network's media server. Which of the following may be why Jason is unable to access the network shares in his home network?

A. The laptop has an IP conflict
B. The laptop must join the HomeGroup (correct answer)
C. The laptop's gateway is not properly configured
D. The laptop's DNS configuration is not properly setup

The HomeGroup for the home network must be joined for the laptop to access the local network's shared files from the network's media server. The rest of the options can be dismissed since the laptop can access the internet successfully and browse the web.

discussion.content: Answer is C. An employee does not have access to change domains. Also, a user will be prompted for credentials if they want to access files from a different domain.

The answer is C, windows has a firewall active by default, and his company may well have one of their own installed.
To everyone determined the answer should be D - Where in the question does it say that his home media server requires homegroup to connect? as others have pointed out homegroup is no longer a thing in newer versions of windows but besides that you CAN configure network shares without it.

The Official Comptia A+ Certification Study guide says: If a certain application that uses the Internet seems to be working okay but isn’t connecting to its online resources, suspect a firewall issue. Make sure that the application is allowed through the firewall in the list shown in Figure 22-4 .

Sadly I couldn't find anything deeper than that. But if it's coming straight from CompTIA I'm gonna believe C is the answer

He wants to connect to devices at home not in office!!!
And Homegroup is not available in Windows 10

comments.content: Where in the question does it refer to Windows 10 or 8? It is C
I meant homegroup
Jason Dion

he HomeGroup for the home network must be joined for the laptop to access the local network's shared files from the network's media server. The rest of the options can be dismissed since the laptop can access the internet successfully and browse the web.

discussion.content: I think the answer is D firstly, but HomeGroup is no longer in Wins 8 and Win 10. So I chose C
I think it's no correct answer her. I would choose if it would stay "A corporate VPN must be enabled".

D . HomeGroup must be enabled
NOT C -- We don’t know if Joe has a firewall enabled – the question doesn’t say. But we do know that file sharing is a network thing always – so the laptop needs to be a part of the home network to use file sharing within that network.
The answer is C because there’s an implicit denied in the firewall . Joe has to go configure exception to allow him access

comments.content: Agree that the answer is D, company-issued is most likely part of a domain or workgroup and as Itt pointed out, most likely configured to use a VPN. Windows Home Group allows devices that are part of the home group to be discoverable.

discussion.content: IMO the answer is D. It's a company-issued device which means it's configured to use a vpn for accessing shares but Joe is trying to connect to his HOME media center, not work.
I think B is the best answer

comments.content: Joe has verified he is connected to the Internet.
Agreed it's VPN, his laptop is connected to the corporate VPN concentrator and thus unable to access his resources at home.
Internet access and local shared access have nothing to do with each other.
If it was the firewall blocking him then he wouldnt have been able to connect to the internet. So the correct answer is VPN.
Actually, if the VPN was enabled, the computer would have access to the company network. Since he cannot connect at all, he is being blocked by the firewall.

choices.C: A firewall exception must be set

questions.question_text:
Ann, an external user, has received several calls from a company asking why she has been sending the company communications with internal users' names in the `from field`. Ann calls a technician and explains she has not been sending any communications and would like this issue fixed. The technician investigates and determines the PC is not infected with any viruses or malware.
Which of the following should the technician check NEXT?

discussion.content: A. Hijacked email [Email hijacking is another form of man-in-the-middle attack, in which the hacker compromises and gain access to a target's email account. The attacker then silently monitors the communications between the client and the provider and uses the information for malicious purposes.]

While it’s not necessarily a malware attack, watch out for hijacked e-mail accounts belonging either to you or to someone you know. Hackers can hit both e-mail clients and Webmail users. If you start receiving some fishy (or phishy) e-mail messages, change your Webmail user name and password and scan your PC for malware.

questions.question_text:
Joe, an end user, just changed his network password. A pop-up box appears a few minutes later, prompting him to enter his password. Joe enters his new network password and is able to continue working. A few minutes later, the same pop-up box appears again, asking him to enter his network password.
Which of the following Control Panel utilities can Joe use to help with this situation?

discussion.content: fair shake of the saucebottle
Makes Sense

I feel like this varies based on where you end up working...

I would've been fired if I made any changes to the plan without consulting a senior engineer, regardless of user acceptance

D.
Stakeholders must buy off on all changes. You should have their contact info before you start the change. If you hit this point, you call them, get a quorum and they can decide if you backout or add the additionally needed changes.
Only if you have been given latitude to make such ad-hoc needed changes would E be the answer.

I personally will stick to D, as stakeholders refers to people involved with the project.
And the tech missed something so the change is due to out of scope.
D says out of scope. But based on the scenario, the configuration should be included on the SOW but was missed. So E should be the correct answer

comments.content: IMO, the statement "The technician needs to make the adjustments quickly" is just there to throw you off. My vote is B.
I agree, I would go with B it's best to follow proper procedures. I'm sure the approval process can be expedited once the situation has been explained to the change board.
I agree. The "quickly" part must be a red herring. Procedure should always be followed.
Can't possibly be "B". As the question says, it needs to be done quickly.

discussion.content:
The technician is not accountable for reporting to stakeholders, despite him/her having the responsibility to perform the work. Thus, the only valuable solution would be to notify the change board for approval (Answer B). The board would get in contact with the stakeholder and decide upon further steps. Bare in mind that there might be multiple companies working on the same project. 
One installation i worked on had 6 companies in charge of performing network installation: one for designing, two for wiring copper, a third for crimping end points, a fourth for integrating the network to the fire detection etc and a fifth for running optical cable. Thus a technician seeing a miss should definitely refer to standard operating procedure.
The answer is D. In the Change request the system owner/stakeholder is listed. In the event modifications need to be made during the change you need Stakeholder approval

comments.content: Another point is that, if the tech does option E, they could be breaking an SLA or other contract as the additional work needs to be billed or something but hasn't been approved.

discussion.content:
I would go with D as the best compromise. The tech has no authority to act outside of the SOW even if it is incomplete or wrong so it needs to be escalated (eliminates option E). Escalating to Change Board is too slow. Project stakeholders giving override will be faster and then option E could follow that.
Make the changes and document it is the fastest but not correct procedure. 
Escalate to stakeholders (or at least up the management line) is slower but correct procedure.
Personally I feel that going to the stakeholders would be best practice.
Really tricky question and answer.

I think E is correct, the question state that the technician is working on a virtual server migration which means the technician is working on a life Network. Hence, an important configuration was missed, going through the process of change approval will prolong the outage. So for the technician to minimize the outage, E is a close answer for this scenario

comments.content: you're correct, it isn't ideal nor real world but multiple other exam prep sites have this same answer

discussion.content: Why not notify the change team and perform the changes?

comments.content: Because this needs to be Quick and that is not a quick process...that is the dilemma they are proposing here. In the end, unless you have been greenlighted to make in process changes out of scope, it is Mother May I, or you'll be looking for a new job due to the inherent risk you introduce void of checks and balances.

discussion.content:
I would have to say that a SOW is created by a Project Manager and the technician that follows the SOW may have missed what is mentioned as "a critical network configuration" It really doesn't say that the "critical network configuration" is not included in the SOW. I would suspect the technician missed the STEP. If so, the technician should be able to just document what he was about to do and just do it because "it's not in addition too"

This is a hard call

Being all google searches point to E as answer I'd have to agree

comments.content: It says the configuration is missing from the original SOW.
sometimes quickly does not mean it's the right thing to do. you should always follow proper procedure and chain of command to cover your ass.
This will not happen quickly as prescribed by the question. I believe that a quick escalation is in order which is bound by an approval authority.

discussion.content: A new SOW must be generated for this additional work. The technician has fulfilled the needs of the original SOW. At the very least, these changes need to go through chain of command.

A. Obtain end-user acceptance for the proposed changes and submit a change plan for additional work.
[A SOW (Statement of Work) must provide clear transparency of expectations in terms of deliverables and COSTs.]
https://sig.org/docs2/WS04_The_Good_the_Bad_and_the_Ugly_of_SOWs_KellyOCG_2016_04_15.pdf
Any additional changes, such as a "critical network configuration change" WILL require extra funding - at a minimum, for labor - above and beyond the original agreement. Somebody has to pay the extra cash. It would be highly unethical and against better business practices to simply do the extra work without any approvals, even if the adjustments must be made quickly - I assume in order to meet the deadline.

questions.question_text:
A technician is working on a virtual server migration project. The technician has already completed the SOW; however, the servers will not work without a critical network configuration that was missed in the original SOW. The technician needs to make the adjustments quickly.
Which of the following best practice processes should the technician perform NEXT?

choices.A: Obtain end-user acceptance for the proposed changes and submit a change plan for additional work.
choices.B: Submit the changes to the change board for approval.
choices.D: Escalate to stakeholders and obtain override approval for out-of-scope changes.
choices.C: Notify the change team of the changes needed and perform the changes.
choices.E: Document the changes and perform the work.
